since_last_update: Partial U.S. federal government shutdown began at 12:01am ET on January 31, 2026 and is expected to be addressed when the House votes Monday February 2, 2026; this raises near-term macro/data-release uncertainty and headline-driven vol risk for index futures. (IBD, Wikipedia)

Fed leadership regime-uncertainty intensified after Trump nominated Kevin Warsh for Fed Chair; market focus shifted to perceived Fed-independence/policy-path risk and the possibility of prolonged institutional friction. (WSJ, MarketWatch, AP)

Precious-metals deleveraging risk increased after CME raised Comex gold and silver margin requirements following historic price declines, increasing odds of forced selling and cross-asset VAR/margin spillovers. (Bloomberg via Mining.com, Reuters via Economic Times)

Geopolitical risk premium in energy remains elevated: oil rallied to multi-month highs late last week on fears of potential U.S. action vs Iran and related supply-disruption tail risks, reinforcing the 'inflation vs risk-off' push-pull for equities and gold. (Reuters, FT, AP)

Risk appetite backdrop weakened into month-end: multiple sources described a risk-off tone with US index futures softer and attention on mega-cap/AI-linked earnings and positioning after a late-week wobble. (IBD, AP)
today_focus: Dominant session narrative check: policy uncertainty is the key macro overhang (Fed chair transition + shutdown optics) and is likely to express via rates/real-yield volatility into Monday’s cash session. (WSJ, MarketWatch, AP)

US equities (ES/NQ): watch whether 'earnings + rates' reassert as the main driver versus headline risk; mega-cap/AI-adjacent prints are positioned to swing Nasdaq beta and broader risk premia. (IBD, AP)

Gold: near-term driver is still positioning/liquidity (post-crash deleveraging + higher margins) rather than clean macro; expect higher gap risk and reflexivity to USD/real-yield moves. (Bloomberg via Mining.com, AP)

Oil-to-equities linkage: elevated Iran risk premium can tighten financial conditions via inflation expectations even if equities are otherwise in 'bad news = cuts' mode; watch for cross-asset correlation flips. (Reuters, FT)

Government shutdown mechanics: treat as a 'data integrity/availability' risk (not just growth) that can distort short-term macro inference and create mispricing around incoming labor/manufacturing prints this week. (IBD, Reuters)

market_pricing.dominant_driver: Policy/regime uncertainty (Fed chair transition + government shutdown) interacting with positioning (metals deleveraging) and geopolitics (Iran/oil risk premium).
what_markets_seem_to_be_pricing: Higher policy uncertainty premium in real yields/term premium: leadership transition headlines are being treated as a catalyst for rate-vol rather than a deterministic 'cuts vs hikes' signal. (WSJ, MarketWatch)

A non-trivial probability of further precious-metals liquidation due to higher margin requirements and recent extreme volatility, with potential spillover into broader risk via leveraged cross-asset books. (Bloomberg via Mining.com)
Geopolitical supply-risk tail in oil (Hormuz / Iran export disruption) that keeps inflation-risk bid alive even if growth/risk sentiment softens. (Reuters, FT)
Near-term growth data sensitivity rising into ISM/JOLTS/ADP, with markets likely to react more through the rates channel given the policy-overhang backdrop. (Reuters)
what_may_be_underpriced: Policy process risk: confirmation/timing frictions (Senate optics, legal/political headlines) extending uncertainty beyond an initial nomination headline, sustaining rate-vol and equity multiple volatility. (WSJ, MarketWatch)
Second-order shutdown effects: disruptions to data releases/agency functions that can create false signals for policy expectations and trigger whipsaws in duration equities. (Reuters, Wikipedia)
Correlation risk: a scenario where oil up + equities down + real yields up occurs (inflation-risk dominates), which is adverse for both growth equities and gold if USD/real yields rise. (Reuters, FT)
Liquidity/market-structure risk in commodities after margin hikes (gap moves, reduced depth) transmitting to index futures via systematic de-grossing. (Bloomberg via Mining.com)

risk_register.risk: Fed independence / policy-path uncertainty persists beyond the nomination headline (confirmation timing, Powell role, political/legal rhetoric) leading to elevated rate-vol and multiple compression risk for duration equities (NQ > ES).
risk_register.timeframe: This week through confirmation pathway (near-term acute; medium-term residual).

risk_register.risk: Shutdown extends longer than expected or meaningfully disrupts key data releases, increasing 'macro signal noise' and raising whipsaw risk around ISM/JOLTS/ADP.
risk_register.timeframe: Next 48–96 hours (House vote Feb 2, 2026; knock-on effects this week).

risk_register.risk: Metals-driven deleveraging: higher margins + recent drawdowns trigger forced selling and cross-asset VAR shocks (gold, miners, broader risk).
Iran escalation tail: oil spikes further, forcing inflation expectations/real yields higher and tightening financial conditions into a fragile risk backdrop.
Earnings concentration risk: a small set of mega-cap/AI-adjacent prints drives index-level moves; disappointment could amplify downside via crowded positioning and vol-control de-risking.

event_warnings: Monday February 2, 2026: ISM Manufacturing PMI (high impact) and ISM Prices—key for 'growth vs inflation' balance and rate-path repricing; watch for equities reacting primarily via real-yield moves.
Monday February 2, 2026: House expected to vote on funding; shutdown-resolution headlines can abruptly reverse risk-off moves and compress front-end uncertainty premia.
Tuesday February 3, 2026: JOLTS Job Openings—can reprice labor slack narrative and shift duration-equity sensitivity (NQ).
Wednesday February 4, 2026: ADP Employment—can set tone into official payrolls later; in this regime, even modest surprises can be amplified by policy-overhang.
Ongoing: any Fed chair confirmation-process headlines / political rhetoric that reframes perceived independence can move USD/real yields quickly, with knock-on effects for gold and tech.
